{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3236583,"name":"","username":"four","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-02T00:17:30.269Z","cooked":"

We are having an issue with setting the offsets of our swerve modules. On enable, they will sometimes go the offsets and claim to be in the correct position, even if they are not. Other times, they will turn to positions that are not the offsets and do not even claim to be correct. All of the CANCoders seem to be working fine with green lights and good reports from self tests.

I saw this but it is already set to boot to absolute.

This specific hardware all worked together last year and updating the wpilib version did necessitate a few changes but I am not sure if that would have any effect.

Code

Update with additional information:
We have managed to isolate one module and get it to behave with some PID tuning. This has had the effect of making everything a bit sluggish (having a delay when responding to inputs or lack of input).

@nstrike We are not using YAGSL right now, but when we were you said that the CANCoder errors that we were getting were indication of an encoder issue. Could these issues still exist and be causing problems even if the light is green and the self test is good?

I do not know exactly. It was forked from 2194 who in turn got it from 4201. I kind of assume that it has some basis in SDS but have no way to confirm that. Do you know how to identify it?

Are you attempting to configure the offsets in pheonix tuner as a parameter?

If they are green and self-test reports they are good then it’s not likely an error with the cancoders. Assuming that you read correct values when manually turning the swerve modules.

If you soldered the CANCoder yourself you may have an issue with the connectivity sometimes under pressure/moving wires.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-10-02T23:46:59.201Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":230,"readers_count":229,"score":51.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":441688,"topic_slug":"swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange/441688/4","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3236932,"name":"","username":"four","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-02T23:51:15.536Z","cooked":"

I have just gotten the offsets to work by tuning the PID a bit. The offsets are configured in the code, but I have gotten the actual number from phoenix tuner.

We did solder the CANCoders, but I do not see any issues other than the occasional “CAN frame too stale”.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-10-02T23:51:15.536Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":208,"readers_count":207,"score":41.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":441688,"topic_slug":"swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60512,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doubling the current limit does not make it work."},"post_url":"/t/swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange/441688/5","custom_user_title":"Doubling the current limit does not make it work.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3236975,"name":"","username":"four","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-03T02:10:54.583Z","cooked":"

Some things are working now. There are two issues that I can see.

  1. The azimuth has a tendency to drift after running for a while. They snap back to zero positions on code restart so I assume this is the NEO550 internal encoder drifting.

  2. The rear drive motors sometimes run the wrong direction. Sometimes they are correct, sometimes wrong. The only consistent thing is that they seem to always be correct when running in the forward/backward direction.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-10-03T02:10:54.583Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":190,"readers_count":189,"score":48.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":441688,"topic_slug":"swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60512,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doubling the current limit does not make it work."},"post_url":"/t/swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange/441688/6","custom_user_title":"Doubling the current limit does not make it work.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3237018,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-03T05:26:57.606Z","cooked":"

I KNOW WHAT THE ISSUE IS! Democat had msde their library have a resetToAbsolute function which synchronized the absolute encoders to the local encoders when the current velocity/requested velocity is 0 and has been for X amount of time. This is because sometimes the absolute encoder doesn’t act correctly sometimes but always fixes itself shortly later.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-10-03T05:26:57.606Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":87.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":441688,"topic_slug":"swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60512,"username":"four","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange/441688/7","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3237021,"name":"Josh Buker","username":"CoolBudy1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/b3f665/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-10-03T06:00:49.705Z","cooked":"

This function was a saving grace for our team. We had to make our own version since we don’t use Democat but it does the exact same thing.

Slapped it into TeleopInit for Robot.java plus a manual button just in case and worked like a charm ever since.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-10-03T06:00:49.705Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":149,"readers_count":148,"score":29.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":441688,"topic_slug":"swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange","display_username":"Josh Buker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50049,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 4692 | Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange/441688/8","custom_user_title":"FRC 4692 | Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3237046,"name":"","username":"four","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-03T12:14:44.150Z","cooked":"

It does not look like we have a resetToAbsolute(). What exactly needs to be added to get that?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-10-03T12:14:44.150Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":32.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":441688,"topic_slug":"swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60512,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doubling the current limit does not make it work."},"post_url":"/t/swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange/441688/9","custom_user_title":"Doubling the current limit does not make it work.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3237053,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-03T12:50:22.686Z","cooked":"
github.com

BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example/blob/main/src/main/java/swervelib/SwerveDrive.java#L785-L792


      
    
          
  1. // If the robot isn't moving synchronize the encoders every 100ms (Inspired by democrat's SDS
    2. 
          
  2. // lib)
    3. 
          
  3. // To ensure that everytime we initialize it works.
    4. 
          
  4. if (sumVelocity <= .01 && ++moduleSynchronizationCounter > 5)
    5. 
          
  5. {
    6. 
          
  6.   synchronizeModuleEncoders();
    7. 
          
  7.   moduleSynchronizationCounter = 0;
    8. 
          
  8. }
    9.

I programmed mine to simply synchronize the encoders when velocity was 0 and the count was above 5 (to have a denounce so i wouldn’t get too high of a CAN utilization). Synchronization is simple too.

If you don’t want to go this route you may have good luck delaying your startup fetch of the absolute encoders by a second.

github.com

BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example/blob/main/src/main/java/swervelib/SwerveModule.java#L192-L194


      
    
          
  1.   angleMotor.setReference(desiredState.angle.getDegrees(), 0, absoluteEncoderPosition);
    2. 
          
  2.   synchronizeEncoderQueued = false;
    3. 
          
  3. } else
    4.

I tried implementing this, but there were so many references that I just went back to the source of your features and tried YAGSL again. This is working now, not noticing much azimuth drift over time.

However the rear modules are still sometimes spinning drive in the wrong direction when in strafe. This is not always and the forward/backward is still fine. It seems that whatever direction they go in first will be correct and the second will not. Not sure how related to this issue it is, but one of the modules is just a little weird sometimes as when drivebase::lock is called it goes perpendicular but other times it seems fine.

Also I do not understand how the two axis rotation is supposed to work, but once activated, it will lock into a spin and keep running after no input has been given. Is this how it is supposed to work?

Looks like the reversing might be happening when the encoder number goes below zero. The dashboard displays a negative for a little bit before correcting to a ~300s number.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-10-04T01:30:20.208Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":99,"readers_count":98,"score":24.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":441688,"topic_slug":"swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60512,"username":"four","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/swerve-does-not-respect-offsets-and-being-strange/441688/14","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3237374,"name":"","username":"four","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-04T11:59:50.481Z","cooked":"

The two heading axes that are passed through AbsoluteDrive() as
() → -driverXbox.getRightX(),
() → -driverXbox.getRightY(),

github.com

Delmar-Robotics-Engineers-At-MADE/ChumChucker3/blob/1cf6239a0a18f8461d4b779a108f564b1b79eebc/src/main/java/frc/robot/RobotContainer.java#L58-L68


      
    
          
  1. AbsoluteDrive closedAbsoluteDrive = new AbsoluteDrive(drivebase,
    2. 
          
  2.                                                       // Applies deadbands and inverts controls because joysticks
    3. 
          
  3.                                                       // are back-right positive while robot
    4. 
          
  4.                                                       // controls are front-left positive
    5. 
          
  5.                                                       () -> MathUtil.applyDeadband(driverXbox.getLeftY(),
    6. 
          
  6.                                                                                    OperatorConstants.LEFT_Y_DEADBAND),
    7. 
          
  7.                                                       () -> MathUtil.applyDeadband(driverXbox.getLeftX(),
    8. 
          
  8.                                                                                    OperatorConstants.LEFT_X_DEADBAND),
    9. 
          
  9.                                                       () -> -driverXbox.getRightX(),
    10. 
          
  10.                                                       () -> -driverXbox.getRightY(),
    11. 
          
  11.                                                       false);
    12.

I have never seen anything like this before and it does some strange things.

AbsoluteFieldDrive() looks like what I am used to with the only heading supplier being () → driverXbox.getRawAxis(2).

github.com

BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/swervedrive/drivebase/AbsoluteDrive.java#L41-L48


      
    
          
  1. * @param headingHorizontal DoubleSupplier that supplies the horizontal component of the robot's heading angle. In the
    2. 
          
  2. *                          robot coordinate system, this is along the same axis as vY. Should range from -1 to 1 with
    3. 
          
  3. *                          no deadband.  Positive is towards the left wall when looking through the driver station
    4. 
          
  4. *                          glass.
    5. 
          
  5. * @param headingVertical   DoubleSupplier that supplies the vertical component of the robot's heading angle.  In the
    6. 
          
  6. *                          robot coordinate system, this is along the same axis as vX.  Should range from -1 to 1
    7. 
          
  7. *                          with no deadband. Positive is away from the alliance wall.
    8. 
          
  8. */
    9.

These values are used to get the angle of the joystick and set the heading to that angle.

I get that. Just a bit confused as to why it takes two DoubleSuppliers whereas AbsoluteFieldDrive() only has one.

It seems like the module I was unable to test last night is going correctly in the forward/backward direction now, but strafe is wrong and when put into rotate or lock() it is rotated the wrong way by 90 degrees.

In AbsoluteFieldDrive it converts a single axis to desired rotation instead of it matching the stick’s orientation

github.com

BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/swervedrive/drivebase/AbsoluteFieldDrive.java#L68


      
    
          
  1. }
    2. 
          
  2. 
          
  3. // Called every time the scheduler runs while the command is scheduled.
    4. 
          
  4. @Override
    5. 
          
  5. public void execute()
    6. 
          
  6. {
    7. 
          
  7. 
          
  8.   // Get the desired chassis speeds based on a 2 joystick module.
    9. 
          
  9. 
          
  10.   ChassisSpeeds desiredSpeeds = swerve.getTargetSpeeds(vX.getAsDouble(), vY.getAsDouble(),
    11. 
          
  11.                                                        new Rotation2d(heading.getAsDouble() * Math.PI));
    12. 
          
  12. 
          
  13.   // Limit velocity to prevent tippy
    14. 
          
  14.   Translation2d translation = SwerveController.getTranslation2d(desiredSpeeds);
    15. 
          
  15.   translation = SwerveMath.limitVelocity(translation, swerve.getFieldVelocity(), swerve.getPose(),
    16. 
          
  16.                                          Constants.LOOP_TIME, Constants.ROBOT_MASS, List.of(Constants.CHASSIS),
    17. 
          
  17.                                          swerve.getSwerveDriveConfiguration());
    18. 
          
  18.   SmartDashboard.putNumber("LimitedTranslation", translation.getX());
    19. 
          
  19.   SmartDashboard.putString("Translation", translation.toString());
    20. 
          
  20. 
          
  21.   // Make the robot move
    22.
github.com

BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/swervedrive/SwerveSubsystem.java#L201-L213


      
    
          
  1. /**
    2. 
          
  2.  * Get the chassis speeds based on controller input of 1 joystick and one angle.
    3. 
          
  3.  *
    4. 
          
  4.  * @param xInput X joystick input for the robot to move in the X direction.
    5. 
          
  5.  * @param yInput Y joystick input for the robot to move in the Y direction.
    6. 
          
  6.  * @param angle  The angle in as a {@link Rotation2d}.
    7. 
          
  7.  * @return {@link ChassisSpeeds} which can be sent to th Swerve Drive.
    8. 
          
  8.  */
    9. 
          
  9. public ChassisSpeeds getTargetSpeeds(double xInput, double yInput, Rotation2d angle)
    10. 
          
  10. {
    11. 
          
  11.   xInput = Math.pow(xInput, 3);
    12. 
          
  12.   yInput = Math.pow(yInput, 3);
    13. 
          
  13.   return swerveDrive.swerveController.getTargetSpeeds(xInput, yInput, angle.getRadians(), getHeading().getRadians());
    14.
